rating.messageWeight: You just logged your weight, great job staying consistent!
rating.messageSession: Great workout! You're part of the warriors who push their limits!
rating.messageGeneral: Thanks for using Yoroi every day!
rating.humbleMessage:
Sorry to interrupt... I know your time is precious.

But if Yoroi helps you in your progress, a quick rating on the Store would help me immensely to grow our warrior family and make the app visible to other athletes like you.
rating.familyGrowing: Every rating helps the Yoroi family grow!
rating.thankYou: Thank you from the bottom of my heart!

weightPredictions.title: Weight Predictions
weightPredictions.introText: Our predictions use validated mathematical models from scientific research to estimate your weight progression.
weightPredictions.targetMessage: At this rate, you will reach your goal of {{targetWeight}} kg in about {{weeks}} weeks
weightPredictions.methodologyDescription: Our predictions are based on the validated energy model from research, which takes into account:
weightPredictions.formulaNote: 1 kg of fat ≈ 7700 kcal (Hall et al., 2011)
weightPredictions.study1Description: Validated mathematical model for predicting body weight changes based on energy balance.
weightPredictions.study2Description: In-depth analysis of energy balance and factors influencing long-term weight loss.
weightPredictions.study3Description: Study on metabolic adaptation during weight loss and strategies to minimize it.
weightPredictions.disclaimerText1: These predictions are estimates based on statistical averages. Individual results may vary depending on many factors: genetics, hormones, stress, sleep, body composition, etc.
weightPredictions.disclaimerText2: Always consult a healthcare professional before starting a weight loss program.

charge.title: Training Load
charge.tutorialDescription: Analyze your weekly training load to optimize recovery and performance.
charge.keyPoint1: Load is calculated based on intensity and duration
charge.keyPoint4: Listen to your body and adjust volume
charge.calculationExplanation: Load is calculated by combining intensity (1-10) × duration (minutes) for each session. A 60 min session at intensity 5 = 300 pts.

recovery.name: Recovery
recovery.description: Active rest phase. Ideal for regenerating muscles and nervous system.
recovery.advice: Take time for stretching or light activity.

balanced.name: Balanced
balanced.description: Moderate load allowing stable progression without overtraining.
balanced.advice: Keep this pace, you're progressing optimally.

optimal.name: Optimal
optimal.description: Ideal zone to maximize gains while recovering properly.
optimal.advice: Excellent load! You're in the maximum progression zone.

intense.name: Intense
intense.description: High load. Make sure to recover well between sessions.
intense.advice: Watch for fatigue. Prioritize sleep and nutrition.

veryIntense.name: Very Intense
veryIntense.description: Risk of overtraining. Plan rest days.
veryIntense.advice: Reduce volume or intensity to avoid injuries.

statsModal.missingProfileDescription: For accurate scientific results, please enter your height and birth date in your profile.

bodyFat.title: Body fat
bodyFat.explanationMale:
Body fat percentage measures the proportion of fat relative to total weight.

CLASSIFICATION (Gallagher et al. 2000, n=1626 subjects):
- 3-13%: Athlete - Competition level
- 14-17%: Fit - Excellent condition
- 18-24%: Average - Healthy general population
- 25%+: High - Increased metabolic risks

SCIENTIFIC EVIDENCE:
- >25% in men = 2.5x type 2 diabetes risk (Prospective Studies Collaboration, Lancet 2009)
- <5% chronic = hormonal dysfunction, weakened immunity

MEASUREMENT ACCURACY:
- Bioimpedance: +/-3-5% error (Kyle et al. 2004)
- DEXA: +/-1-2% (clinical reference)

ADVICE:
Follow the TREND over 4-8 weeks rather than daily variations.
bodyFat.explanationFemale:
Body fat percentage measures the proportion of fat relative to total weight.

CLASSIFICATION (Gallagher et al. 2000):
- 10-20%: Athlete - Competition level
- 21-24%: Fit - Excellent condition
- 25-31%: Average - General population
- 32%+: High - Increased metabolic risks

BIOLOGICAL DIFFERENCE BETWEEN MEN/WOMEN:
Women naturally have 8-12% more fat than men (breasts, hips, reproductive reserve). This is NORMAL and HEALTHY.

SCIENTIFIC EVIDENCE:
- <15% prolonged = amenorrhea, infertility (Loucks AB, J Sports Sci 2004)
- >32% = increased diabetes/cardiovascular risk

ADVICE:
A loss of 0.5-1% per month is a healthy and sustainable rate.

muscleMass.title: Muscle mass
muscleMass.explanationMale:
Skeletal muscle mass (SMM) represents the voluntary muscles in your body.

CLASSIFICATION (Janssen et al. 2000, MRI study on 468 subjects):
- <38%: Low - Probable sarcopenia
- 38-44%: Normal - Sedentary population
- 44-52%: Good - Regular physical activity
- 52%+: Excellent - Athletic level

SCIENTIFIC EVIDENCE:
- +10% muscle mass = -11% all-cause mortality risk (Srikanthan P, Am J Med 2016)
- Muscle = metabolic organ: secretes anti-inflammatory myokines
- Positively correlated insulin sensitivity

SARCOPENIA (Cruz-Jentoft AJ, Lancet 2019):
Loss of 3-8% muscle per decade after age 30.
Strength training is the #1 scientifically validated treatment.

RECOMMENDATIONS (ACSM):
2-3 strength training sessions/week, all muscle groups.
muscleMass.explanationFemale:
Skeletal muscle mass (SMM) represents the voluntary muscles in your body.

CLASSIFICATION (Janssen et al. 2000):
- <31%: Low - Probable sarcopenia
- 31-36%: Normal - Sedentary population
- 36-42%: Good - Regular physical activity
- 42%+: Excellent - Athletic level

BIOLOGICAL DIFFERENCE:
Women naturally have 30-40% less muscle mass than men (testosterone 10-20x lower). This is NORMAL.

SCIENTIFIC EVIDENCE:
- Strength training = post-menopausal osteoporosis prevention (Kohrt WM, Med Sci Sports 2004)
- No "bulking up" in women without steroids
- Improves insulin sensitivity and metabolism

RECOMMENDATIONS (ACSM):
2-3 strength training sessions/week. Heavy weights are safe and effective.

waterPercentage.title: Body water
waterPercentage.explanation:
Total body water (TBW) represents about 60% of weight in adult men and 50-55% in women.

CLASSIFICATION (Watson et al. 1980):
- <50%: Probable dehydration
- 50-54%: Slightly low
- 55-60%: Normal
- 61-70%: Optimal - Excellent hydration

SCIENTIFIC EVIDENCE:
- Muscle = 73% water, Fat = 10% water (Wang Z, Am J Clin Nutr 1999)
- 2% dehydration = -10-20% performance (Sawka MN, Med Sci Sports 2007)

WHAT INFLUENCES THE MEASUREMENT:
- Time of day
- Recent meals
- Exercise, temperature
- Caffeine, alcohol

DAILY NEEDS (IOM 2004):
- Men: about 3.7L/day (all sources)
- Women: about 2.7L/day (all sources)

ADVICE:
Monitor urine color: pale yellow = well hydrated.

visceralFat.title: Visceral fat
visceralFat.explanation:
Visceral fat is the deep fat surrounding organs (liver, intestines, heart).

SCIENTIFIC CLASSIFICATION:
- Score 1-9: Optimal - Minimal cardiometabolic risk
- Score 10-14: High - Probable metabolic syndrome
- Score 15+: Very high - Significant cardiovascular risk

SCIENTIFIC EVIDENCE (Després et al. 2008):
Visceral fat is the #1 factor of "metabolic syndrome":
- Increases systemic inflammation (CRP, IL-6)
- Insulin resistance leading to prediabetes
- 2x to 3x cardiovascular risk

WHAT WORKS (meta-analyses):
- Aerobic exercise: average 6.1% reduction (Vissers et al. 2013)
- Moderate caloric deficit: primarily targets visceral fat
- Stress reduction (cortisol = visceral storage)

MEASUREMENT:
MRI remains the reference. Bioimpedance gives a correlated but not exact estimate.

hrv.title: Heart Rate Variability (HRV)
hrv.explanation:
HRV measures the variations between each heartbeat in milliseconds.

CLASSIFICATION (RMSSD, average values):
- 70+ ms: Excellent - Optimal recovery
- 50-69 ms: Good - Good adaptation
- 30-49 ms: Normal - Recovery in progress
- 10-29 ms: Tired - Physiological stress

INDIVIDUAL VARIABILITY:
Compare to YOUR average over 7-14 days. Absolute values vary by age, fitness level, genetics.

EVIDENCE (Task Force 1996 + meta-analyses):
- Low HRV = independent predictor of CV mortality (Thayer JF, Neurosci Biobehav Rev 2012)
- HRV reflects sympathetic/parasympathetic balance

WHAT LOWERS HRV:
- Overtraining
- Alcohol (even moderate)
- Chronic stress
- Infection/illness
- Lack of sleep

IMPROVEMENT:
- Regular aerobic training
- Slow breathing (6/min)
- 7-9h sleep

MEASUREMENT:
Morning upon waking, same conditions, for 1-5 min.

restingHeartRate.title: Resting heart rate
restingHeartRate.explanation:
Resting heart rate is an independent predictor of cardiovascular mortality.

CLASSIFICATION (Fox et al. 2007, meta-analysis 46 studies):
- 40-60 bpm: Athlete - Very efficient heart
- 61-70 bpm: Excellent
- 71-80 bpm: Normal - Population average
- 81-100 bpm: High - Increased CV risk

SCIENTIFIC EVIDENCE:
- +10 bpm resting HR = +20% CV mortality risk (Cooney MT, Eur J Prev Cardiol 2010)
- HR <60 bpm associated with better long-term survival

TRAINING EFFECT:
- Regular endurance: -10 to -15 bpm in 3-6 months
- Elite athletes: 35-45 bpm (physiological bradycardia)

ACUTE FACTORS:
Stress, caffeine, dehydration, fever, lack of sleep

MEASUREMENT:
Morning upon waking, before getting up, for 1 minute.

sleepDuration.title: Sleep duration
sleepDuration.explanation:
Optimal sleep duration for health.

CLASSIFICATION (Cappuccio et al. 2010, meta-analysis 16 studies):
- <6h: Insufficient - +48% mortality risk
- 6-7h: Short - Slightly increased risk
- 7-9h: Optimal - Minimal mortality
- >9h: Long - +30% mortality (may indicate pathology)

SCIENTIFIC EVIDENCE:
1.3 million subjects analyzed:
- <5h/night = +52% cardiovascular risk
- 6-8h = minimal risk
- >9h = associated with depression, inflammation

INDIVIDUAL NEEDS:
- Athletes: 9-10h for optimal recovery (Mah CD, Sleep 2011)
- Genetics: 3-5% are true "short sleepers"

SLEEP HYGIENE:
- Regular schedule
- No screens 1h before
- Room 18-20°C (64-68°F)
- Avoid caffeine after 2pm

recoveryScore.title: Recovery score
recoveryScore.explanation:
Recovery score estimates your ability to perform and train.

CLASSIFICATION:
- 0-33%: Red - Rest recommended
- 34-66%: Yellow - Moderate training possible
- 67-100%: Green - Optimal capacity

SCIENTIFIC BASIS (Plews et al. 2013):
The score combines several indicators:
- HRV (heart rate variability)
- Sleep quality
- Resting HR
- Perceived fatigue

INTERPRETATION:
- Occasional low score = normal after intense effort
- Chronic low score = overtraining risk

ADVICE:
Adjust your training intensity to your recovery score.

bmi.title: Body Mass Index (BMI)
bmi.explanation:
Body Mass Index (BMI) = Weight (kg) / Height squared (m²)

CLASSIFICATION (Prospective Studies Collaboration 2009):
Meta-analysis of 57 studies, 894,576 subjects:
- < 18.5: Underweight - Increased mortality
- 18.5-25: Normal - Minimal mortality
- 25-30: Overweight - ~+30% mortality
- 30+: Obese - ~+70% mortality

SCIENTIFIC EVIDENCE:
- Optimal BMI = 22.5-25 for minimal mortality
- +5 kg/m² above 25 = +30% cardiovascular mortality

RECOGNIZED LIMITATIONS:
- Does not distinguish muscle/fat
- Less reliable: athletes, elderly, Asian ethnicities

ADVICE:
Complement with waist circumference (WHtR) and body fat percentage for complete assessment.

waistCircumference.title: Waist circumference
waistCircumference.explanationMale:
Waist circumference measures abdominal fat, a cardiovascular risk factor.

NOTE: Absolute thresholds (90cm/35in, 102cm/40in) are GENERAL benchmarks.

MORE PRECISE METHOD - Waist-to-Height Ratio (WHtR):
Divide your waist by your height:
- < 0.4: Possible underweight
- 0.4-0.5: Ideal zone
- 0.5-0.6: Moderate risk
- > 0.6: High risk

CONCRETE EXAMPLES:
- 5'9" (175cm) height → Ideal waist: 28-34" (70-87cm)
- 6'3" (190cm) height → Ideal waist: 30-37" (76-95cm)
- 6'11" (210cm) height → Ideal waist: 33-41" (84-105cm)

EVIDENCE (Ashwell et al. 2012, meta-analysis):
WHtR BETTER predicts cardiometabolic risk than BMI or waist alone.
"Keep your waist to less than half your height"

MEASUREMENT:
At navel level, standing, after normal exhale.
waistCircumference.explanationFemale:
Waist circumference measures abdominal fat, a cardiovascular risk factor.

NOTE: Absolute thresholds (80cm/31in, 88cm/35in) are GENERAL benchmarks.

MORE PRECISE METHOD - Waist-to-Height Ratio (WHtR):
Divide your waist by your height:
- < 0.4: Possible underweight
- 0.4-0.5: Ideal zone
- 0.5-0.6: Moderate risk
- > 0.6: High risk

CONCRETE EXAMPLES:
- 5'3" (160cm) height → Ideal waist: 25-31" (64-80cm)
- 5'7" (170cm) height → Ideal waist: 27-33" (68-85cm)
- 5'11" (180cm) height → Ideal waist: 28-35" (72-90cm)

EVIDENCE (Ashwell et al. 2012):
WHtR is a better predictor of cardiometabolic risk than BMI or waist alone.

MEASUREMENT:
At navel level, standing, after normal exhale.

boneMass.title: Bone mass
boneMass.explanationMale:
Bone mass represents the mineral weight of your skeleton.

CLASSIFICATION (proportional to body weight):
- <2.8 kg: Low - Osteoporotic risk
- 2.8-3.2 kg: Normal
- >3.2 kg: Good - Optimal density

VARIATION BY WEIGHT:
- 60kg (132lbs) = about 2.6 kg bone expected (~4.3%)
- 80kg (176lbs) = about 3.3 kg bone expected
- 100kg (220lbs) = about 3.8 kg bone expected

SCIENTIFIC EVIDENCE (Kanis et al. Lancet 2002):
- Peak bone mass reached around 25-30 years
- Loss of 0.5-1% per year after 40
- Osteoporosis = T-score < -2.5 (DEXA)

VALIDATED INTERVENTIONS:
- Strength training: +1-3% bone density (Martyn-St James M, Br J Sports Med 2009)
- Calcium 1000-1200mg/day + Vitamin D 800-1000 IU/day
- Impact sports: running, jumping

LIMITATIONS:
Bioimpedance estimates mass, not density. DEXA = reference.
boneMass.explanationFemale:
Bone mass represents the mineral weight of your skeleton.

CLASSIFICATION (proportional to body weight):
- <2.2 kg: Low - Osteoporotic risk
- 2.2-2.5 kg: Normal
- >2.5 kg: Good - Optimal density

FEMALE RISK (Kanis et al. Lancet 2002):
- 1 in 3 women will have an osteoporotic fracture after 50
- Estrogen drop at menopause = loss of 2-3%/year for 5-10 years

SCIENTIFIC EVIDENCE:
- Peak bone mass: 25-30 years
- Strength training = #1 validated intervention
- Calcium + Vitamin D = essential

PREVENTION:
- Strength training with weights 2-3x/week
- Calcium 1000-1200mg/day
- Vitamin D 800-1000 IU/day
- Avoid prolonged very low-calorie diets

ADVICE:
Build your "bone bank" before 30. After, the goal is to MAINTAIN.

bmr.title: Basal Metabolic Rate (BMR)
bmr.explanation:
Basal metabolic rate (BMR) = energy burned at complete rest over 24h.

YOUR ESTIMATED BMR: about {{bmrValue}} kcal/day
(Based on: {{weight}}kg, {{height}}cm, {{age}} years)

MIFFLIN-ST JEOR EQUATION (Mifflin et al. 1990):
Validated on 498 subjects, +/-10% accuracy vs indirect calorimetry.

TOTAL EXPENDITURE (validated activity factors):
- Sedentary (1.2): about {{sedentary}} kcal
- Lightly active (1.375): about {{lightlyActive}} kcal
- Active (1.55): about {{active}} kcal
- Very active (1.725): about {{veryActive}} kcal

INFLUENCING FACTORS:
- Muscle mass: +13 kcal/kg muscle/day
- Age: -2% per decade after 20
- Genetics: +/-5-10% variation

ADVICE:
Increase your BMR through muscle mass!

intensity.title: Training intensity
intensity.explanation:
Training intensity measures relative effort compared to your maximum capacity.

CLASSIFICATION (Banister TRIMP model):
- 0-50%: Light - Active recovery
- 50-70%: Moderate - Aerobic zone, base endurance
- 70-85%: Intense - Lactate threshold zone
- 85-100%: Maximal - Anaerobic zone

SCIENTIFIC EVIDENCE:
- 80% volume in zone 1-2 + 20% in zone 4-5 = optimal polarized distribution (Seiler S, Int J Sports Physiol 2010)
- Overtraining = too much volume in zone 3 (no man's land)

ADVICE:
Most of your training should be in the easy zone (conversation possible).

trainingJournal.title: Training Journal
trainingJournal.deleteTrackingConfirm: Delete this tracking and all its history?
trainingJournal.deleteTechniqueConfirm: Delete this technique and all its notes?
